segments.text: So I wanted to write a textbook on biological oceanography, which was to comprise production biology without fisheries.
Fisheries is so large a subject, and there is so much known about that.
And the production biology of the plankton and of the benthos, and touch upon biogeography, which, as I mentioned earlier, is a very important part of biological oceanography.
But at Scripps, then, I very early saw that, for practical reasons,

To finish half of it before it's getting outdated, I would have to split it into two volumes, and so I split Bentos and Biogic, or Geography, off, and then, when leaving Scripps, thought of a book on Plankton.
But, and I write the other book later, but now after hiring Jumas,

I realize now how little I know in benthos that I'm just completely outdated and so I will not attempt benthos so that I'm left with the plankton which is alright but again for practical reasons the field has grown so much that I think I will restrict myself now to a phytoplankton book something like patterns of phytoplankton distribution in space and time in the ocean or something like that and
then perhaps tackle the Zohar Plankton later.
And it ought to be written at the next sabbatical eve, because now I know how to do it.
What not to do, I have made all the mistakes.
So let's hope for the best.
There is no book yet, so it is still worthwhile doing it.
The writing and the necessity to read now very broadly again brought back my interest in methods in plankton research.

In effect, I wanted to pick up numbers, good examples to illustrate my points, and when thinking about these numbers, which I'd used in class for umpteen years, when thinking about it now, writing it down, I suddenly saw it can't be this way.
And it turned out very often, no, because there were basic mistakes made of data collection or data interpretation.
I've since then written quite a few papers, which have made quite a few colleagues angry, perhaps, saying that this is wrong and that was done incorrectly.
So in other words, I'm back to plankton methods, not so much to say how to put the hydrochloric acid into the vial, but rather

saying now suppose you want to find out such and such you can't use this route you have to use that approach or suppose you have this data you can't interpret as people have done for 20 years in this way no you have to think of this and that this kind of method I'm interested in which in other words to try to keep them honest really which still means no shipboard work
The polykit work I had already alluded to is not really appropriate in an oceanography department.
I can't train students, so half of my research work is done in a field where the students can't emulate me and where I can't get money for research support either.
My continued interest in really evaluating data which exists already, be it textbook writing or worrying about methods, means
not collecting new data, that means not going out to sea, nor standing in the lab.
So the students really don't see me work.
And I think this is not very good.
I don't give them the example.
which is too bad, that it's just the way it is, but I do want to mention that part of the academic teacher is to give an example.
And if the academic teacher is very nervous and always has his door shut and works on data, the students always wonder, well, shall we disturb him, shall we not disturb him?
That is not a good example.
Whereas Duckdale, for example, is always out at sea, he meets his group every day over the coffee pot, so there's a very different way of teaching, and that shows in his students.
But it's too bad.
I just had to finish these polygates, and as I said, there is no textbook, so somebody has to sit down.
And then, of course, the newcomer, who has just lectured twice about Balashur, thinks now he knows everything, ought not to write a textbook.
As I mentioned earlier, I put my notes from
the early days in a textbook form but good that I didn't start writing because obviously it couldn't have had much depth.
If I now were to start
active work again, then I think it will be in plant production, in animal production.
As I mentioned, I know now how little I know about the benthos.
I don't think that I could contribute much to the phytoplankton research, and I think much is left in zooplankton research.
But in contrast to my earlier work, which was concerned with distribution, I think now more has to be done in the lab.
Through the modeling effort, well, because for the modeling effort we need the coefficients.
But through the modeling effort, I also have learned what the problems are with work at sea, with substantiating models at sea.
And here I agree very much with Dugdale, who continues to go to sea to check his theories.
I think because of the...
I'll put it this way.
If you want to test...
our ideas about growth rates of zooplankton, independence of food supply and the effect of predation, we have to really come back to the same population, revisit the same population several times.
But that can't be done in the open ocean because of the currents.
So in the open ocean you always have to compound or always
The open ocean always compounds the time and the space issue.
And in order to verify a model or test a model, you have to keep the space domain separate from the time domain.
And what you are interested in is usually the development in time.
So I feel very much attracted now by, oh, I am convinced that if we were to apply our model ideas and our laboratory coefficients to natural waters, we have to go to enclosures.
We have to enclose the water and thus then come back to the same populations every day or every week, whatever it is.
Now, an enclosure, of course, is not an entirely natural situation.

but in the marine domain but of course in freshwater a lake is a natural unit and that is enclosed water so I have now taught this during at the occasion of recent job offers of going to limnology many of the processes in water in plankton at least are the same there's lots of literature to draw on and shouldn't
or might it not be that the important, the next big step forward in secondary production of plankton be made by the limnologists by virtue of them being able to revisit population.

So I developed more and more interest in limnology, which is of course easy because in the department of zoology, he is an eminent zoologist, eminent limnologist Edmondson, from whom I greatly benefited.

So there is something to be said about lakes, but if I do not change the terminology, then the next step would be to work on large plastic enclosures, as they are now being developed in several parts of the country.
So the point being to revisit populations and test whether you can describe the future state of population from the initial state,
by means of a model, and then test whether your prediction, the future state, is correct.
That is what I think is important.
In other words, I don't think that by going out to sea, with a model as Daktil or without a model as Said, we will get very far.
But that is my opinion.
And I guess that is all.
That is what I'm going to do next, hopefully the textbook, and of course continue teaching, obviously, along these lines, and do something about secondary production.
And the key idea being to focus on population we can revisit.
Any regrets on how your career went?
Do you wish you'd made a different choice along the way?
No, I don't think so, no.
Well, of course, would I have to do it again?
I would, or if I have to advise somebody how to do it better, is to take, having better training, more mathematical training.
That is where I'm very, very weak, such that I sometimes can't read the literature, leave alone do original work.
And nobody told me, how could I know?
That is my great weakness.
But otherwise, no, no regrets.
In hindsight, these years in India seem to be wasted, but then I discovered an upvailing area, so that's all right, I guess.
And some people have served two years in the army and regard that as wasted.
No, I don't have regrets.
And Seattle is very pleasant to live.
And so you're happy you opted for an American university?
Yeah.
Although in university life, of course, never things are permanent.
It's not out of the question that I would go back to Europe, but it's unlikely because I had several offers and each time there was a flaw in the ornament.
